testimony: Good Morning everybody.  When we adjourned yesterday Mr Visser was about to call his next applicant.

Morning, Mr Chairperson, Members of the Committee.  Yes Chairperson, I call Maj Salmon Johannes Gerhardus du Preez, who is ready to give his evidence.  He prefers to give it in Afrikaans and he has no objection to taking the prescribed oath.

Mr Chairperson, before you has been placed a summary of his evidence which we submit should be marked Exhibit C.  This was done yesterday and I will draw your attention to some mistakes that have been made in it, but we'll deal with it when we come to it.  If I may then lead the witness, Mr Chairman?
Mr du Preez, you have previously testified ...(intervention)

Before you proceed, it's just been drawn to my attention, we were given a map yesterday.  I think at this stage, seeing we've marked this one C, we'll mark the map Exhibit D.  Have you all got a copy of that map?  Thank you.  Sorry, Mr Visser, you may proceed.

Thank you, Mr Chairman, yes, that is Exhibit D.  Mr Chairman, we will attempt to obtain a map with greater detail about the particular area which is relevant here, which is Phoenix/Bambayi/kwaMashu and if we do obtain such a map, we'll let you have that immediately.
	Mr du Preez, you have testified previously before other Amnesty Committees as it is mentioned in Exhibit C?
And you have also completed an application for amnesty which is bound into the Khubeka bundle, that would be bundle 1?
Pages 30 to 41, where the incident is dealt with by you from page 31 to 34?

Do you confirm your previous evidence as well as the incorporation of your evidence, into your evidence of Exhibit A, which is now serving before the Committee and you request that this be taken into consideration when your application is considered?
Will you please turn to page 2 of Exhibit C and explain your participation in this incident to the Committee and your knowledge of the surrounding circumstances?

Chairperson, during 1987 I took part in the arrest of one Nthombi Khubeka.  I was then a Lieutenant and served under the direct command of Colonel, then Captain, Botha.
	I confirm that information was known that she was involved, in that she acted in a co-ordinating capacity between externally trained terrorists and locally trained terrorists.

Just for the sake of interest Mr du Preez, I understand that if a person, during the struggle, had been trained internally, that person was not referred to as a terrorist by you, he had to be trained externally, is that correct?
What is the difference between a terrorist trained outside the country and one trained inside the country?
The local persons were trained to commit acts of terror similarly as persons who were trained outside.
Is there a difference between persons who were trained outside the country with regard to the combat of the struggle of the past as you have seen it and the persons trained inside the country?

She was responsible for the storage of weapons, the provision of accommodation to terrorists and the gathering of intelligence with regard to targets of terror.  Her family were well-known activists in kwaMashu.  It was decided to infiltrate her and her structure of co-workers and collaborators by members of C1 who had rendered service at that time in Durban and surroundings.  Members of C1 succeeded in establishing contact with Khubeka.
You have heard that Mr Botha had testified that this was done by means of an informant?
Did you know about that, or did you not know about that?
I was aware of that.  I did not know the finer details though.

Over the course of many days, members of Vlakplaas reported that Khubeka had confirmed that she acted in a co-ordinating capacity and had played a leading role with regard to accommodation of externally trained terrorists in kwaMashu and had shown arms to them which she had stored on the terrorists' behalf.
May I just ask you, Mr du Preez, to clear up something here?  You say that she admitted that she acted in a co-ordinating capacity.  To whom did she admit?
But she admitted to them without knowing that they were members of C1?
So actually they said that they had information because admit indicates and accusation and then she had admitted it, it was not that she admitted it.

That's correct.  They pretended to be trained terrorists.  The idea was to try and apprehend the terrorists by making use of Khubeka.  An appointment was made on a day that the leader of the group...(intervention).
Sorry, can I just ask again for it to be a little bit slower?  Thank you.  If you can start that paragraph ...(intervention)
Sorry, maybe if you could just go a little bit slower please so that the interpreter can get it and so that we can keep up with the notes, particularly Mr Wills who has to take it all down.

The idea was to try to apprehend these terrorists by making use of Khubeka.  An appointment was made on a day that the leader of the group of terrorists, who was hidden by Khubeka, to be arrested.  The person had to be lured to a place which had been agreed on beforehand, namely the Durban beach front at Battery Beach.
Sorry Mr du Preez.  Battery Beach, is that the beach that is in front of the old Military Command headquarters?
That's correct Chairperson.  That was the part between there and it was also known as Sunkist.
Is it near where the snake park used to be there?

Col Botha, van der Westhuizen, Basson and I had by late that afternoon, held surveillance at this place.  Mbane would give a sign if the terrorist or terrorists were with him in the motor vehicle.  The windows of his vehicle were tinted so that we could not see inside.
Can you recall what type of vehicle it was?

A Corolla.  Now that Mbane arrived there and had parked there, he gave the sign after a short while.  We struck, only to find that Khubeka was alone with Mbane in the vehicle.  We then arrested her and she was immediately removed from the vehicle and taken to our vehicle.
Mr du Preez, the vehicle which you referred to as "our vehicle", what type of vehicle was this?
It was a Toyota panel van, a kombi.
A panel van, does it have windows on the sides and at the back?
It only has one set of windows where the sliding door is.
What was your part in this so-called arrest?  What did you do exactly?
Chairperson, I can recall when Nthombi came out of the vehicle...(intervention)
Please refer to her as Khubeka.
When Khubeka was removed from the vehicle, I grabbed her from behind and lifted her.  I lifted her up and moved to the vehicle, so she was half dragged and half carried to the kombi.
How far from the Toyota was the kombi?
I don't think it was more than 10 metres.
Can you give a description of the build of Khubeka?
She was a large woman and overweight.

I was given instruction by Col Botha to take her to the old S A S Police shooting range at Winkelspruit for interrogation.  At that stage we had used the shooting range as an operation bases.  There were ablution facilities and storage rooms.  We had indeed slept there some evenings and some of the askaris also stayed there during their visit on this occasion.
	It was already dusk when we arrived at the shooting range.  After I had handed over Khubeka to Col Taylor or Col Botha, I departed, for I had other obligations.

Sorry, Mr du Preez, what do you mean "after you handed her over to Col Taylor, or Col Botha"?  Did you hand her over to both of them, or one of them, or can't you remember to whom you handed her over?
I think both of them were there and I handed her over to both of them, or both of them received her.
But Botha was with you in the vehicle, how could you have handed her over to him if he was with you and in control of the operation?

I cannot recall where Botha was, whether he was in front in the kombi.  I was in the back of the kombi and I held Khubeka under control and what I mean by that is, when we arrived at the camp, I handed her over to them.

Yes, but the way you've written this and the way you've just testified is that when you got there you handed her over to them, one or the other, in other words that they weren't with you.  His evidence is that he was with you in the vehicle.  Do you see the difference?
What I mean here, Chairperson is that she was no longer under my control.  I did not exercise control over her any longer.
You see his evidence was that more than just you had to subdue her and put her in the vehicle.  You weren't acting on your own.
There were five of you at least, according to what he told us.

And - so I'm just a little puzzled why you've used this expression that you "handed her over", as if you had formal control over her and then you passed her on to the next level of control.  You'll concede, that's the impression you create here.
But he had control over all of you because he was the officer in control at the scene and in the vehicle, not so?
It is definitely so.  He was your Commanding officer at that point.
Mr du Preez, can you recall today that in your memory, Mr Botha was with you in the same vehicle when you travelled to Winkelspruit?
Who was second in Command after Capt Botha at that stage?
I was in command after Botha.
Very well, will you please proceed?  You say that you handed her over to Taylor or Botha or both and then you wanted to say?
I then departed, for I had other obligations.  With my return later I was informed that Khubeka had died, possibly of a heart attack.
Can you recall who told this to you?
Very well.  It may then be so that with the drawing up of the statement I had erred, but will you please continue with paragraph 13?
Col Taylor requested Sgt Wasserman and myself to dispose of the body in the vicinity of kwaMashu where it could be found.
I would like to ask you, was Col Taylor alone when he spoke to you and Wasserman?
Chairperson, if I recall correctly, at the time of this conversation, Col Taylor, Botha, myself and Wasserman were present when Taylor informed us that we had to dispose of the body.

Because Mr Botha testified that his recollection is that he requested you to dispose of the body.  It is possible, Chairperson, because there was a discussion.  As far as I can recall the final instruction came from Col Taylor.

Very well.  If I may refer you to paragraph 17, we will return to paragraph 14 and then what is written here is not strictly speaking correct.  You say
"My motivation to execute the instructions of Col Botha..."
What would be the correct situation?
That would be Taylor and Botha, Chairperson.
Will you then proceed at paragraph 14, or rather, "in the vicinity of kwaMashu, to dispose of the body in the vicinity of kwaMashu".
Mr Botha's recollection is that he requested to you dispose of the body close to her home.  Can you recall that?
Mr Visser, may I just interpose here?  Mr du Preez, did I hear correctly that you said there was a discussion, or did I not hear correctly?  It may be possible that I did not hear correctly.
That is correct.  I said that there was a discussion after Botha had informed me that the person, Khubeka, had died.  I, Col Taylor, Wasserman and Botha held a discussion.
So you confirm that you used the word "discussion"?  So I would want to hear briefly what was the content of this discussion, so we can get clarity about this.
The discussion was that Taylor and Botha informed us that the body had to be disposed of close to her home.
But that is not a discussion, Mr du Preez, that is an instruction.  I would like to arrive at the discussion.  Did you just receive an instruction, or was there a discussion?
Chairperson, it was just said that we had to take the corpse and drop it off close to a place close to her home.
So that was actually an instruction?
To what I referred to as a description.
I do not want to split hairs, but a discussion has a far wider implication.
The way I recorded it and I was listening to your Afrikaans and just translating it myself, but you said that you discussed the matter.  I assumed that was the matter of her death.  Is that right?
Botha told me that she died of a heart attack.
And you said that immediately after that you and Wasserman, Taylor and Botha had a discussion.  Was that discussion about what to do about it?
That is correct.  That is where Botha and Taylor told us what to do with the body.

... (indistinct) that discussion as I understood from your evidence.  That was the impression you gave me, that you and Wasserman, Taylor and Botha all discussed what the next step would be and finally you got an instruction to dump the body.  Have I understood you correctly?
Chairperson, it was not my decision,

I'm not saying it was your decision, I'm saying, were you part of the discussion about what to do with the body and then finally you got an order after the discussion was concluded.  Have I understood you correctly?
Chairperson, Wasserman and I were present when Taylor and Botha decided what to do.
Did you contribute to that discussion?
So you were just present, they spoke about it in your presence and then they informed you of their decision?
Thank you, Mr Chairman.  And when you received the order, what did you do?
Sgt Wasserman and I executed the order and dropped her off in the grass next to the Inanda road, near Bambayi.
Now before we get to that, where was she, the body of Khubeka, when you had to transport her?

She was in a storage room, she lay in a storeroom and Wasserman and I waited until all the members were asleep or were away, I cannot recall.  The camp was quiet and then we drove the vehicle until it was adjacent to the storeroom, we picked up Khubeka and placed her in the boot of the car.
Was her body wrapped in anything?
Can you recall the appearance of the clothing?
Can you recall the colours of the clothing, even though you cannot recall the items of clothing themselves?
In what vehicle did you transport her?
Your private vehicle, or was it a police vehicle?

The place where you and Wasserman dropped her off, you say this was in the grass next to the Inanda road.  Could you just give a finer description to the Committee of how far away from the road this was and also if you could perhaps provide some form of a landmark or something in order to indicate to us where precisely you dropped the body off?

Chairperson, it was next to the road, opposite the Ghandi settlement, there's a place there known as the Ghandi settlement and Bambayi would be on the opposite side against the hill slope.  And it was in that area between Ghandi settlement and Bambayi.
Did you think that the body would be discovered there?
Yes, Chairperson, we left her approximately 15 metres from the road and I was certain that somebody would find the body there.
Were there any signs that people were moving through that area where she had been dropped?
Yes, Chairperson, during the day there were many pedestrians there, it is a taxi route.
And was it your own experience that there were people moving about there during the day?
And if a body were to be found there, where would the nearest police station be where one could report this from that point?
kwaMashu would have been the closest.
Were there also any other police stations in that vicinity?
The nearest police stations, that would be Phoenix and Inanda police stations.
Sorry, before you proceed, Mr Visser.  Are you saying the nearest police station is kwaMashu, then the next nearest is Phoenix?
Were there any state mortuaries in the vicinity where bodies which were found would be taken to?
As far as I knew there was a state mortuary in kwaMashu.
Did you know where Mrs Khubeka resided?
I did.  She stayed in G Section.

Now G Section, if one consults Exhibit D and follows the line from the M2 in a north-easterly direction, then there is a railway line, it would appear due to S A R which is stated next to it, that runs from kwaMashu north in the direction of Inanda.  Is that correct?  Do you see it?
Now if you were to take the railway line as a point of reference, was G Section on the left side, that would be the western side, or the right side being the eastern side of that railway line?
That would be on the left side, the western side.
Very well.  That area there, is it rural or are there many people living there?  What is the position in that area where you left the body?
It was a big open grass field at that stage.
No, I'm referring to that area.  Were there any homes nearby or not?
No, there were no houses near that place at that stage.
Very well.  Would you continue with paragraph 16, beg your pardon, 15?
I did not report the incident and consequently I made myself guilty of defeating the ends of justice.
Yes and other offences with regard to bodies, isn't that so?
From documents now before the Committee, it is alleged that Khubeka's body was exhumed and that it was found that she had a bullet wound in the back of her head.
Yes, we know that the bullet wound is actually on the top of her head, but continue.
I know that she did not have any bullet wounds.  According to me and Wasserman, her body was dropped off next to the Inanda highway, near Bambayi.
Yes, and there is a reference, for the information of the Committee, to the TRC report.  Please continue, paragraph 17.

My motivation to carry out the orders of Col Botha by abducting Khubeka and afterwards dropping off her body, was an action in support of the liberation attempt against the revolutionary onslaught and especially to spare the government and the SAP political embarrassment during a period of time when there was much criticism, both internally and internationally, against the government.
	The ANC used all events which indicated at offences of the Security Forces and made propaganda out of it in order to place the government in the worst possible light.  My actions were aimed at the protection and maintenance of the former government and constitutional dispensation.  
	The acts and omissions which I committed, I committed in the execution of my official duties under the order of a higher officer, whose orders I was obliged to execute.  I did this as part of the opposition to the struggle and my actions were aimed against supporters of the liberation movement.
And the next sentence is a repetition.  Please continue with paragraph 22.
As such I believed bona fide that what I did fell within my express or implied authorisation.  I humbly request that amnesty be granted to me for my acts and omissions in this regard.

And as previously stated or indicated by the Chairperson of this Committee, during argument you will be led regarding - it will be discussed exactly what you have applied for and you request amnesty for that?
Mr Chairperson, I again neglected to ask something.
Mr Visagie -  can you recall whether, during the events of the particular evening upon which Mrs Khubeka died, whether you saw him there at the scene?
Therefore you wouldn't really be able to say what his share was, if any, in this event?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VISSER
Yes, thank you.  Mr Nel, do you have any questions you'd like to put to the witness?
Thank you Mr Chairman, only one.
Mr du Preez can you recall in any way whether Mr Spyker Myeza was involved in this incident in any way on that evening or that day?

No, I cannot recall.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR NEL
Mr van der Merwe, do you have any questions you'd like to ask?

I have no questions, thank you Mr Chairman.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR VAN DER MERWE
Ms Botha, do you have any questions you'd like to ask.  Just for record purposes, Ms Botha is standing in for Mr Hugo who is involved in another matter held in these same premises.
Mr du Preez, during the meeting and delivery at Battery Beach, did you in any way see Mr Simon Radebe there in the vicinity?
I cannot recall.  I cannot recall whether I would have been able to identify any of the persons as being present there.
Because Mr Radebe will say later that he drove the vehicle and because he was seated behind the steering wheel, he activated the indicator light, but you cannot recall seeing him there?
And when you arrived at Winkelspruit, you were sent to buy food, how long were you away?
I cannot recall the length of time which I was away, all that I can recall about the incident is that when I returned Botha, informed me about the death of Khubeka.
And when you returned after buying food, did you see Mr Simon Radebe anywhere there in the area?

Thank you.
NO FURTHER QUESTION BY MS BOTHA
Can I just follow up?  Did you go and buy food, or did you go and get on with other duties, because your evidence so far is that you went and did other duties?
I think that among others I went to buy food.

Sorry, where would you have gone in relation to the place, the shooting range at Winkelspruit, to buy that food?  Would it have been very close by or would you have had to drive some distance, or did you walk there?
Chairperson, I cannot recall precisely what I went to do.  My recollection of the incident is that when I returned, Botha told me about the incident.
How long were you away for?
I cannot recall.  I cannot say with certainty.
Was it several hours, or was it 10 minutes?
Sorry, Mr Chairman, maybe in the light of these questions, there's just maybe one question which I neglected to put to the witness.
Yes, Mr van der Merwe you may ask questions.
Mr du Preez, in terms of these questions, my instructions from Mr Baker are that on that specific evening he also drove with you when you went to buy food, do you recall anything like that?
I do not recall who accompanied me.  It is possible that he drove with me.
And that at the stage, when you returned, he was with you when you were informed that Mrs Khubeka had passed away.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VAN DER MERWE
Thank you.  Mr Samuel, do you have any questions you'd like to ask the witness?
Maj du Preez, on the morning in question, do you recall what were the instructions given to Mr Jimmy Mbane, or Mr Radebe for that matter?
No, Chairperson, I did not speak to them.
Were you present at the meeting when the instructions were given to either Mr Radebe or Mr Jimmy Mbane as to what they should do in regard to Ms Khubeka?
Do you know any reason as to why Ms Khubeka was brought to Mr Botha and yourself on that day?
Chairperson, when we departed for the beach front, I understood that the C1 members would bring the terrorists to this rendezvous point.
If I may interpose, Mr Samuel?  You've just referred to terrorists in the plural that were going to be brought to this point, have I understood you correctly?
Chairperson, that is what I understood, that we would meet a terrorist or terrorists there, that they would bring a terrorist or terrorists to the rendezvous point.
What were you going to do at the meeting place with the terrorists?
So one or more would be irrelevant, you were going to arrest whoever came to that place?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.  Mr Jimmy Mbane will confirm that he was given instructions to pick up Ms Khubeka from the Durban station and bring her to Battery Beach, but going on from there, do you recall who was in the vehicle that brought Ms Khubeka?
No, Chairperson, I cannot recall who the persons were.
So if Mr Radebe and Mr Dube were present in that vehicle, you would not be able to recall that.  Am I right?
Mr Mbane's version will be that when they came to Battery Beach with Ms Khubeka, Mr Radebe and Mr Dube were present in the vehicle.
Do you recall whether you met Mr Jimmy Mbane after he had handed over Ms Khubeka to yourselves?
You mean on the same day?
Now, do you recall whether Ms Khubeka was handcuffed or tied up when she was put into the vehicle in which you were in?

Chairperson, I cannot recall whether she was cuffed during the journey to Winkelspruit but in the kombi we pressed her down.  It was a panel van which was open at the back.  There weren't any seats in the vehicle and she was blindfolded.

Mr du Preez, is it not so that it would have been common practice to cuff somebody in those circumstances? I mean when you detain a person, or abduct a person, or apprehend a person, wouldn't it just be second nature for you or any other policeman to cuff the detainee?

That is correct, Chairperson, but I cannot recall specifically whether this was done or not.  We would have kept her under force.  As far as I can recall, after she had been placed in the vehicle, she did not struggle to break loose or anything like that.

Thank you.  Thank you, Mr Chairman.  Maj du Preez, Major Mr Jimmy Mbane will tell this Commission that when he arrived back at Winkelspruit with Mr Dube and Mr Radebe, he had noticed that Ms Khubeka was tied both hand and foot and she was also blindfolded.  Can you admit or deny that?

Chairperson, I recall that she was blindfolded.  I cannot recall that her hands and her feet were bound.  If her feet were bound, she would certainly not have been able to walk and we would have had to carry her and we didn't do that.
How was she blindfolded?  Can you recall?
It was a piece of cloth, or a piece of sheet.  Possibly a piece of sheet or a pillow case.
Wouldn't you also want to have her hands cuffed, most likely behind her back, in order to prevent her from tampering with the blindfold, pulling it off?
Chairperson, we were with her all the time and she wouldn't have been able to do anything like that.

Mr du Preez, anybody, whether you were right there, you weren't holding her by her arms the whole time.  You said she was just on the floor of the vehicle.  If her hands weren't tied, she could easily have pulled the blindfold off.  I mean, that's just so patently obvious.

Chairperson, in such a case, when a person is held under force, you would tell them to be seated, you would tell them what to do, so that such a person wouldn't have a choice, they are kept under force and they are being told what to do and what is expected of them.
And you people did that, and you remember doing that?
It is possible, Chairperson, but I cannot recall.

Are you suggesting to this Commission that throughout this ordeal and after you all had put her into your vehicle, she had given you no resistance?  Is that what you are suggesting to ...(intervention)
That's not what the evidence is, Mr Chairman.  He says there was resistance at the time of the arrest and thereafter, once she was put in the car, there wasn't resistance.

Yes, he said that when she was in the vehicle, she didn't struggle.  I can't recall precisely what was said about taken to the car other than she was half dragged and half carried.  I don't know if, perhaps you can ask a question on that, Mr Samuel.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.  Major, when Ms Khubeka, who was, in line with your evidence, she was a big built woman, overweight as you put it, did she give any resistance at that stage when you all dragged her out of the motor vehicle in which Mr Mbane was?
Chairperson, I cannot say exactly, she had no choice, we seized her and half picked her up and carried her.  She did not kick or scream.  We overpowered her completely.

Why did you do that Major?  Why not just go up to her and flash your card and say "Look, come with us, we're the police" and let her walk to the vehicle?  Why have a whole group of you go in there and grab her?
Chairperson, we were prepared to seize whoever would be in the car and to take them to our vehicle.  That was our plan and that is how we executed it.

May I just ask you, did you know immediately that this was Ms Khubeka, because you actually expected to find terrorists who had been trained abroad, as I understand it.  Did you realise that this woman was Ms Khubeka?
Chairperson, it was only once we had her in the vehicle that I realised it was her.  We expected terrorists, but we also planned to seize everyone who was in the car and to arrest them.
Did you look into that motor vehicle to see whether there were any other persons in that motor vehicle?
I did, Chairperson, and Ms Khubeka was the only person who I recognised as someone who was not a C1 member, that is why she was the only person who was seized.
How many of you all went to this motor vehicle to carry Ms Khubeka out?  Do you recall?
Chairperson it was me, Sgt van der Westhuizen, W/O Basson, Col Botha and I think that there were also members of C1 involved, but I cannot recall who from C1 was there of the white members of C1.
Prior to this day in question when Ms Khubeka was handed to you, did Mr Mbane hand over any other people, other terrorists to you or to your group?

Mr Mbane will say that he handed two persons to you, among them was one Sbu and you were present when he handed over Sbu to you all, who was also an ANC activist and later Sbu was killed by your group.
That he handed him over to me or in my presence?
Do you know anything about the man called Sbu?
It's a very general name, but I don't know of the Sbu that the speaker is referring to.

Thank you.   Now, if Mr Mbane informed his  handlers, Mr Botha and Mr Taylor about Ms Khubeka's suspicions regarding two people that were supposed to be given safe-houses by Mr Mbane, would you know about that?
No, Chairperson.  Botha informed us about what was important regarding the operation and I cannot recall anything like that specifically.
If any payment were made to Mr Mbane by Mr Taylor, would you know about it?

Thank you.  Major, I'm going to put Mr Mbane's version to you.  You can either admit or deny the contents of it.  Mr Mbane will tell this Commission that on the day in question he was requested by Mr Radebe to pick up Ms Khubeka from the Durban station and bring her to Mr Botha together with yourself and other members at Battery Beach.  Do you agree with that?
That is correct, Chairperson and I accepted that terrorists or a terrorist would be present.

If I may interpose here, you're answering in a very general way and the question was quite specific.  Mbane says his instruction was to pick up Khubeka.  You've answered yes, that is so, we were expecting terrorists.  Did you know about Khubeka specifically or didn't you?
I knew that Khubeka was involved with these terrorists and that Mbane and the others worked with Khubeka, that this was their contact person.
So did you expect her to be in the vehicle that day?
It was possible that she would be in the vehicle.
And that she would be amongst the terrorists that would be picked up?
Just before I proceed, I just want to find out one thing.  If Ms Khubeka was screaming during this ordeal, would you know about it?
While she was being beaten prior to her death.
After arriving back at the shooting range.
Chairperson, at no stage did I participate in her interrogation.
Yes, but I think the question relates to screaming.  Did you hear any screaming?
Why wouldn't that be so?  Was she not screaming, or you just didn't hear it?
The time when I dropped off and delivered Khubeka to Taylor and Botha, she never screamed and during the time that I was there, I never heard her scream.

Right.  Mr Mbane will say that after he had handed over Ms Khubeka to Mr Botha and yourself and the other members, he had then returned to Winkelspruit where he had met you all at the Winkelspruit shooting range.
I cannot recall that Mbane arrived there.
Didn't they sleep there, the members of C1?
Yes, but they moved around quite a bit, during this time they were away quite often.
He will also say that when he got back to the shooting range, he noticed Ms Khubeka was both blindfolded and tied, both hands and feet.
And he is more specific in regard to how she was tied.  He says she was tied with a piece of rope.

He will say on occasions whilst Ms Khubeka was being interrogated and beaten, the door was open and he noticed Mr Botha and Mr Taylor both on some occasion or the other hitting Ms Khubeka with a whip.

And he will say also that the reason why Ms Khubeka was specifically asked to be brought to Mr Botha and yourselves, was that Ms Khubeka had informed him that there was a handler or a Commander of two men and Ms Khubeka had handed of to Mr Mbane to find safe-houses for and she wanted to see them and she was becoming suspicious.  He further will state that he told Mr Botha and you were present at that time and Mr Taylor about Ms Khubeka's suspicions and Mr Botha had instructed him to bring Ms Khubeka to him.
I was not present during such a discussion.

The question is, how many C1 members were there present?  How were they organised?  What was your back-up plan?  What fire power did they have, if this is a case where you are arresting potentially dangerous people?
Chairperson, I never doubted the fact that we were enough people to handle the situation.

Well, I just put it to you that the way you've described the arrest appears to me to be more fitting for the arrest of one person, i.e. the planned arrest of Nthombi Khubeka and not other ANC persons as has been testified.
Now, did you indicate that Ms Khubeka struggled at all during the process of her arrest?
Chairperson, she was grabbed, she was lifted off her feet and taken to the kombi and this was accompanied by the necessary violence to keep her under control.
My question was, did she struggle?  Did she try and run away?  Did she try and resist arrest in any way?  You were holding her, you would know that.
Not that I can recall.  She was taken violently to the kombi.
What do you mean by violently?
Against her will.  She was picked up.
...recall her thrashing her arms about or trying to kick you or anything like that?
No Chairperson.  She also did not shout.
So you'd be surprised if she got injured in any way in the process of her arrest and in her transportation to the Winkelspruit shooting range?
I don't know of any injuries that she may have had, I don't believe that she had any injuries.
And you don't believe she would have been injured in the process of your arresting her and you carrying her to the car?
So if it was later proved that she did in fact have broken ribs, you would say that that must have occurred after you handed her over, in your words, to Capt Botha?
Now, just describe the interior of the panel van.  Was it a Toyota Hi Ace, a kombi type panel van or a Venture type panel van?
It was a Toyota panel van, such as a Post Office bus.  It was a bus which was very empty, completely empty at the back with a wooden floor covered in carpeting.
It's basically like a Toyota minibus but without the windows and seats?
That would be the same type of vehicle.
That is correct, except that it wouldn't have windows on the sides.
And Ms Khubeka was placed  on the floor of this?
She was told to lie still and we told her that we were the police.
Yes.  Did you not have to physically restrain her in any way?
No, Chairperson, after she was in the vehicle, she didn't put up any fight, she accepted that she had been arrested or that she was under our custody.
Yes and who else, if you can recall, came with you in the kombi?
I cannot recall Chairperson, but it must have been van der Westhuizen, Boshoff and Botha.
You say Boshoff, is that Basson or Boshoff?
I beg your pardon, it is Basson.
Why do you use the phrase "must have been"?
Because all of us arrived there in that vehicle.
But earlier on in your evidence you weren't sure, are you now sure?
I cannot recall any other vehicle.

No, but we know that the vehicle that Ms Khubeka was transported to Battery Beach also went back to Winkelspruit later on.  Who travelled in that vehicle?  We would assume Mbane would be one of the people.
I cannot even recall that they returned.
I cannot recall seeing them again.
But in short, you're not positive as to who was in the vehicle with you?
Chairperson it was me, Botha, van der Westhuizen and Basson and I think that there was another member of C1 but I don't know who he was.
I cannot recall who sat where or who drove the vehicle.  I can recall that I sat in the back of the vehicle with Nthombi.
Sorry, in that vehicle, how many people can sit where the driver sits, including the driver.  You get the driver and then, is it a bench seat, or is it room for only one other person in the front?
There is room for three people to sit in front.
There were other people in the back with me.
Can you remember how many people were sitting in the front and how many people were in the back?
So how can you be sure that these people were in fact with you in the car?
Chairperson, there were others in the back of the vehicle with me and there was the person driving the vehicle, but I cannot recall who it was who drove the vehicle and who sat in the back with me.
So in other words you don't know who was in the vehicle?  You're making assumptions post facto.
Chairperson, the persons who were with me in the vehicle were van der Westhuizen, Botha, Basson and I cannot recall who the C1 member was.
Now, if it wasn't your intention to arrest Khubeka, why didn't you just take her and detain her and put her through the normal police processes?
Chairperson, she would be interrogated about the terrorists whom she knew about.

That still doesn't change the question.  You could have still questioned her.  Why take her to the shooting range?  Why not question her at C R Swart in the normal course of a Section 29 detention, which you would have been perfectly entitled to use?
Chairperson, she would probably have been taken to C R Swart later for detention.
The question is why take her to the shooting range?
Chairperson, that is the point from where we operated and that is where we were going to interrogate her?
I'm asking you why did you take her there?

Why do you take her to a place that is hidden from all the other people, and hidden from where she's essentially denied all of her rights?  What was the reason for that?  You took her to a secret hide-out where you conducted these activities, why was that?

Why couldn't you just take her to the normal police station and interrogate her in the cells at C R Swart?  Book her in like a normal arrest.  Why was there the need to take her to this other place?  Can I help you?
Isn't it because you wanted to beat the living daylights out of her, without anybody else finding out?
I put it to you it was.
Well, can you give me another reason as to why she wasn't taken to the police station?
Chairperson, the reason why we took her there was to interrogate her.  That was the premises from where we operated at that stage.
Sorry, at that time, I can't recall, was there any state of emergency prevailing?
Just - my recollection is that there was.  I wouldn't know the specific date but 1987, middle of that year there was definitely a state of emergency on the go.
You can accept that there was, Mr Chairman.
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  How did you expect that she was going to be interrogated?
I accepted that Botha and Taylor would interrogate her.
Yes.  What methods did you expect that they were going to use?
Chairperson, I didn't have any preconceived ideas.

What methods were usually used?  Is it that you sat down and had a cup of tea and said:  "Mrs Khubeka, nice to meet you.  We've heard about your family in Lusaka.  How are they doing now?  Please tell us about what's going on."
Chairperson, such discussions did take place.  There were such interrogations.
I put it to you, you would have foreseen the likelihood that she would have been assaulted in that interrogation.
Not necessarily.  If a person co-operated he or she would not be assaulted.

But you see, the impression I got from Mr Botha's evidence was, he said that while she was being interrogated, she was being beaten by Col Taylor and as far as he was concerned, Taylor was beating her not because she was not co-operating but just to stress the seriousness of the occasion to her.  In other words, it was a sort of gratuitous type of beating, it wasn't done with the intention to get her to talk, that was the impression that Mr Botha said that he had.  She was being beaten from time to time by Taylor, just to stress the seriousness of it.
Chairperson, I would not be able to comment on that.  During my time when I interrogated people, I cannot think that I would have assaulted someone if he or she had co-operated.
Yes, but from your answer you say that on the one hand, had she not co-operated, she would have been beaten.  You would have expected that?
Let's not beat around the bush with respect.
Well, Mr Chairman, what's wrong with the answer?  Who's beating around the bush?
He's cross-examining, he can persist with his line I think.
But Mr Chairman, there's no reason to be discourteous to the witness.

That wasn't my intention, with respect, Mr Visser and if it was I apologise, if I am being discourteous.  I'm trying to get to the truth of this matter.  Was it not a probability that she would be beaten, if she wasn't co-operative?  It's not a possibility, it's a probability?

Mr Chairperson, I cannot testify now about things during which I was not present.  I don't know what the circumstances were surrounding this entire interrogation, therefore it is difficult for me to give you an answer regarding this.
You testified that if she co-operated, she wouldn't be beaten and if she did ...
That is what I believed and that is what I still believe.
Yes.  My question is that it seems to me likely that if somebody doesn't co-operate, then the chances are they're going to receive a bit of a hiding in order to get them to co-operate.
So in that regard, you must have at least foreseen the possibility of her being assaulted when she was taken for interrogation?
There was a possibility that she could have been assaulted.
And you knew that at the time you arrested her and you were, as you were taking her to this torture chamber.
It did not occur to me.
What occurred to you?  What did you think was going to happen to her?
I knew that she would be interrogated.
And that the possibility was that she would be assaulted during that interrogation?
Did you see any sjambok at all in the office or in the room where it was?
Did you see a length of black piping in that room?
Did you go into the room prior to her interrogation commencing?
I was in that room previously, but upon my arrival at the premises, I did not enter the room.
Where was Mr Taylor when you arrived?
I cannot recall.  I cannot recall whether he stood outside or where it was that I met him.
So your evidence is to the effect that you - sorry I withdraw that question.  You'd been out, one must imagine for some hours, away from that place that day prior to you returning with Khubeka?
So you cannot say what was or wasn't in that room, or what had been brought into that room in the intervening period?
Did you go into the room at all during the interrogation?
I was never present during the interrogation.
Was there any particular reason for that?
Shortly after I arrived and delivered the person, as I have stated, I departed.  It would seem as if you're uncertain as to the reason why you departed, or am I mistaken?  Why did you depart?
I went to deal with other duties and also to buy food.
Did you buy food for the detainee?
When you say you went to buy food, were you going to buy food for everyone who was sleeping, for all the C1 members, was this a - or were you just getting take-always?
I assume that it was take-away meals, food for those people who were there, or those who wanted food.

But Mr du Preez, that would have entailed you knowing how many people to buy for, what each one might want.  It would be something that you would have taken specific instructions on, you wouldn't have just gone to buy a "klomp wegneemetes", as one would put it, you would have known.

Chairperson, in this specific case, I cannot recall precisely what I bought, but usually we would buy Kentucky or if there were 10 persons, it would be 10 hamburgers.  So I cannot recall specifically what I bought.
Did you go alone when you went for the food, or did you go with somebody?

Sorry, just while we're on this thing, you went to go and do other duties you say, in your summary of your evidence here, the written summary.  I have canvassed this with you already a little bit, yet you can't remember what those other duties are.  Have I understood you correctly?
Well if you can't remember what those other duties are, how can you remember at all that you even went to do other duties?

Chairperson, the reason why I recall is because I was away from the place and when I returned, upon my arrival there Botha informed me that Khubeka had died and I was very surprised about it and the reason why I say this, that I know that I was away, is because I arrived back at the place and Botha informed me about Khubeka who had died.

...one iota of a clue as to why you remember you went to do other duties.  All you know is that you left the place and you came back, but you don't know what you did, you don't even know if  you went to buy food, you don't even know if somebody else was with you or not, do you see my point?  You don't remember what you did, so how can you be so sure you went to go and do other duties?  That's the point I'm trying to understand.  If you simply said, "I left, I don't know what I did and I came back" that would be find, I would accept your evidence, in that sense is would make sense to me, but now you insist that you went to do other duties and you can't explain what you did or give me a reason how you know those were other duties.  Do you see my point?
No, Mr Chairperson, I cannot recall specifically what I went to do.
You might have gone home to your family.
With me it was an assumption that I went to do other things.

Thank you, Mr Chairperson.  My experience of the military is that the lower ranking persons are sent to do the menial tasks like collecting food and the commissioned officers, as you are, are to do the serious work.  Isn't that usually the case?
So were you frequently asked to go and get food?  I think you were a Lieutenant in those days?
That is correct.  There were not specific duties for specific persons and I did not regard it as inferior to go out to buy food or to perform any other duty.

Now, you say it was dusk at the time you arrested the deceased?  Then it would take, I would estimate, knowing where Winkelspruit is, probably half an hour to drive - was it dark when you arrived?  We're looking at winter time, autumn/winter?
Chairperson, I recall that it was already far into dusk, or almost dark when we arrived at the place.
Are you able to give a time?  6 o'clock, or 7 o'clock, or anything like that?
How long were you away before you returned?  How many hours, minutes, seconds?
I don't know, I cannot give you an exact time.
Are you able to say whether it was more than an hour, or less than an hour?
Now when you arrived there, who put the deceased into the torture chamber?
Mr Chairman, who said it was a torture chamber?
It hasn't been referred to as a torture chamber, but I think it was referred to as a room or a storeroom.
Possibly I can use the word interrogation, if that makes my learned friend feel more comfortable?
The evidence was it was a storeroom into which she was taken, Mr Chairman, that was the evidence.
The evidence is also it's a place where she was severely beaten and she died in.
Yes well, let's just refer to it as a room, I think and we'll all understand that.
Who placed Ms Khubeka in the room where she subsequently died?
I cannot recall, Chairperson.  I delivered Khubeka to Taylor and Botha was also present.
...remember how, if she was assisted to get out the car, or anything along that nature, out of the bus, sorry, the panel van?
I cannot specifically recall that she was assisted, but she was blindfolded and she would have been picked up and brought out.
I may have assisted with that.
When you got back, you say, your evidence is seemingly not certain, you're not sure whether it was Taylor or Botha who informed you that she died.
It was Botha who told me that she had died.
And what exactly did he say to you, to the best of your recollection?
He told me that Khubeka had died of a heart attack, or that she had had a heart attack and died.
Did he tell you how long ago this had occurred?
Did you get an impression that it was just immediately before you arrived, or she'd been lying there dead for some hours, or minutes?
I did not formulate an opinion about that.
Did you go and take a look at the body that is prior to the time that you say after you had waited and loaded it into the Skyline, did you go and take a look at it?
No, Chairperson, I didn't go.  I went into the room to fetch her when we loaded her into the vehicle to go and drop her off.
I assume when you went into the room to collect her, you would have switched on a light in that room, her body that is?
There was a light in that room.
The question was, did you switch it on when you went to fetch the body?
I cannot recall that.  I cannot recall whether the light was on, or whether I switched it on.
But you can recall that it was on then, the light was on?
That is correct.  I saw the person lying there.
Whereabouts was the deceased lying in the room?
She lay in the room.  I cannot say precisely what her position was, but when I entered the room she lay on her back in the room.
She was lying on her back?
That's what he said.  She was lying on her back.
As far as I can recall.
And you went in with your colleague, I think it's Wasserman.
And how did you pick her up and put her into the boot of the Skyline?
Wasserman and I picked her up by her arms and also by her feet and then put her into the boot of the car.
Did you notice anything in the room at the time you picked her up?  Anything unusual?
Chairperson, as far as I can recall the room was empty, there wasn't anything else in the room.
When you're saying empty, there was no furniture even, it was just four walls and a floor?
As far as I can recall.  I cannot recall whether this was on that day or at a later stage, there were
I beg your pardon Chairperson, I couldn't hear the witness when he states what was in the room?
There were shooting targets in the room.
Was there urine on the floor?
Chairperson, as far as I can recall it was wet, the body of the deceased was wet and I also believe that water had been poured on her, because there was water on the floor.
Was there blood on the floor?
Why are you so sure of that?
Because I would have seen blood if there had been blood.
Would have you seen marks on her body?
I did not disrobe her, she was clothed.
Can you remember what clothes were there?
Can you remember if it was a jersey?
One would imagine that had she been beaten as described by the previous witness, that she'd have marks on her arms and her back.  Not so?
I didn't notice that.  I didn't see any marks which fixed my attention on the fact that she had been assaulted or struck.
Yes, but what I'm trying to suggest is that you would have noticed if she had bare arms and there were marks on her arms, you would have noticed them.
No, Chairperson.  Dark person's would not mark the same way that lighter persons would.  I cannot recall that I saw any marks on her and I did not inspect her specifically for any marks.
If her arms were bare and there were bruises on her arms from a sjambok, is it likely that in the circumstances of you picking her up that you would have noticed those bruises?

She was hit hard on numerous occasions with a sjambok and the evidence is that she tried to fend off the blows with her arms.  What I'm suggesting is that you would have noticed it, had her arms been bare.

I think perhaps maybe wheel marks, because I don't know how long it takes a bruise to form and I don't know if a bruise can form after a person has died, but perhaps if  you could ask about wheel marks.
Chairperson, I did not see any of those marks.

My point is slightly different.  You see, the evidence is that she was wearing a long-sleeved sweater and what I'm trying to get out of you is that had she been, had she not, sorry let me rephrase completely.  Our evidence will be that at the time she was wearing a long-sleeved sweater and I'm suggesting to you that had she been wearing a garment that didn't cover her arms, and had she been assaulted in the manner that has been previously described, you as an experienced policeman would have noticed bruises on her arms, so the implication is that the possibilities are good that she'd been wearing something that covered those marks?
I cannot remember anything like that, Chairperson.
Now, did you clean up the room afterwards?
Singular, now or in the plural again?
Thank you.  Were you involved personally in the clean-up of the room?
When you got back in the morning at sunset, did you never establish that or were you never tasked to do that?
I cannot recall that I went back to that room.
Was there a domestic servant employed there at any stage?
So one of the persons present would have obviously had to do some cleaning up, even if it's just to wipe up the urine and the water?
That's correct Chairperson, but I was not involved in that.
Who do you think would have been involved in that, with your knowledge of the operation?
Was this not a menial task left to askaris?
I would not be able to say, Chairperson.
Did you do a thorough inspection of the room when you were removing the body?
No, Chairperson, my attention was drawn to the body when I went into the room.
So there is a possibility that other objects might have been in the room which escaped your attention?

Can you describe, your evidence to this effect confused me.  Can you describe to the best of your recollection exactly what order you received after being involved in the discussion with Col Taylor and Mr Botha as regards disposing of the body?
No, what order you received.  I think it's common cause that you received an order to dispose of the body.  I'm wanting to know exactly what the content of that order was.
Chairperson, the instruction was that we would dispose of the body in a place close to her home.
So why did you choose the place where you dumped the body?
Chairperson, it was an open field.  It was a quiet place, there were no houses in the vicinity, so the possibility of us being seen was remote.

Mr du Preez, were you told why it should be, or did you know why it should be close to the home?  Were you told to hide the body that it never be found again, or was there anything, any instruction given to you in any more detail other than, dispose of the body near the home?
No, Chairperson, it was said we have to drop her off at a point where people would find her, where she would be found and she could be identified.
So why did you drop her off in a quiet place?
Chairperson, that is a place where many taxis pass during the day so at that time during the night it was a quiet place, but during the day it's a very busy place.
Would you be able to point out to us exactly where this place is today?
Now, I'm sure Mr Visser will correct me if I'm wrong, but my recollection is that Wasserman was involved in the interrogation, do you recall the evidence whilst you've been listening here?
I saw by means of the statements that Wasserman was involved in the interrogation.
Mr Chairman, yes, he was present during the interrogation.

Now no doubt as you were surprised that this death had occurred, you would have discussed the circumstances surrounding this death when you were driving with him to dispose of the body.  I want to know what was said then.
Chairperson, Capt Botha had already informed me that the person had died of a heart attack.

The question was, when you and Mr Wasserman were now driving off with the body, did you not discuss the circumstances of the death, didn't you say "What did you see?  What happened?"  Wouldn't it have been a natural thing  for you to have talked about?
I cannot recall that we discussed it, Chairperson.

Surely you would have been a little bit curious to know how it was that she came to have a heart attack?  It's one thing to be told yes, she had a heart attack, but surely your curiosity would have at least piqued some discussion.
Chairperson, I cannot recall at all that Wasserman told me anything about the assault.  I heard about the assault only afterwards.

I'm not asking you about the assault.  I'm not saying anything about assault.  I'm saying surely your inquisitiveness, your curiosity, just as an ordinary person, would have been, how did this woman come to have a heart attack?  And if you knew that Mr Wasserman was present, as you would have known at the time, you would have said to him , "Well Lawrie tell me what happened, this is a bizarre situation."
Chairperson, they had already told me how the heart attack had taken place.
So you already knew all that.
Did you and Wasserman talk about anything in the car?
Chairperson, I think we discussed or where we spoke about where we would dispose of the body and we drove looking for a suitable place.
And who decided amongst you, where the body would be disposed?

As far as I can recall Chairperson, we drove in the direction of kwaMashu and we passed kwaMashu and we said, I cannot recall whether Wasserman or I decided, but we decided that this was as good a place as any and we will drop it off there.
And tell me, how did you get the body out of the car, in detail?

We pulled the vehicle off the road and we waited to see if everything was quiet and whether there were any persons walking around on the road or whether vehicles were approaching and then we took her out of the boot and carried her for about 10 metres into the field.
Was the car on the side of the road or was the car partially in the bush?
It was off the road completely.
And how did you carry the deceased?
We used the same method, under her arms and by her feet and carried her.
You can't remember whether you were carrying her legs?
Do you remember if she had shoes on?
I cannot recall, I assume she was fully clothed.
Did you notice whether or not she had a ring?
Did you notice whether or not she had panties on?
When you drove back, what did you talk about in the car?
Did you sleep at the shooting range that night?
No Chairperson, I think we only returned early the next morning.
So where did you go to in the intervening period?
I think we spent the evening at our homes.
So after dumping the body off, what did you then do and what did Wasserman then do?  Who dropped who off?  Where?
I think Wasserman dropped me at my home and then he left and then he picked me up the following morning and we went back to the shooting range.
You said that it was your vehicle.  Was it the usual that you exchange the car?
When you were dumping this body what was going through your mind?  Didn't you think you were doing something wrong?
Chairperson, it was a very unpleasant task.
Did you feel any sympathy for the deceased?

Now, why was it to the best of your recollection, why was it decided that the deceased's body should be dumped close to her home?  You said you were part of - you didn't participate in the discussion, but you were present when Botha and Taylor were deciding what to do with the body.
That's correct, Chairperson.  It was their decision.
Yes, but why?  What was the reasoning?  I'm wanting to know, you heard that discussion.
So that her body could be found.
Chairperson, we couldn't anything with the body.

No, but why didn't you just dump it somewhere else?  I mean there must have been some purpose for dumping it close to her home as opposed to just dumping it in the Tugela River, or dumping it in the Umzimkulu River, I'm wanting to know what the reason was.
Or seeing that the cause of death was a heart attack, leaving it on a park bench somewhere?
Chairperson, that was Botha and Taylor's decision.

Look, I'm asking you, with respect Mr du Preez, you said and your evidence was that there was this discussion that went on between Botha and Taylor and you were present while this discussion was going on, I'm asking you what were the reasons for that discussion?  Why was it decided that she was dumped in this particular way?
The idea was that she would be found and that the family would identify her and that she would have a normal burial.
So you're wanting us to believe that the purpose was so that her family would know that she was dead?
So that she would be found and she would be identified by people in her area.
But I can't understand because that seems out of sync with the other matters that I've been involved in here in the sense that why was it necessary that you wanted the family to know about her death?
Chairperson, as I've already said it was Botha and Taylor's decision.  I cannot help if it is out of sync with any other things that had taken place.

You see, it would seem to me that in line with your intention to distance yourselves from her arrest in any way, that it would be a safer option to dispose of the body in such a way that nobody would ever identify her and that it would be better for example that the story that she had gone to Mozambique would be the one that was circulating because then your operation wouldn't stand any chance of being compromised, not so?
Chairperson, I think it was brought about by the fact that she had died of natural causes.
No, with respect, that doesn't gel.  It is clear that had her body been found, the wounds from her assault would have been apparent to anybody doing an immediate inspection, not so?
Most probably sjambok bruises would be found on her but it would not have caused the death of her.

No, I know that.  But had a pathologist or a district surgeon found that she'd been sjamboked, that would have raised suspicion, it wouldn't have appeared to him that she had died of natural causes, it would have looked as if she'd been beaten to death.  Maybe a murder docket might have been opened.

Well, it's more likely, with respect, but anyway, I put it to you that you are lying when you say that you wanted to dump the body in such a way that she'd be recognised, or that it would be found out by her family that she had died.
I put it to you that you intended to arrest her on that day, that you intended to torture her and to get information out of her and whether or not she died, was irrelevant to you.
I put it to you that her death was expected by you and all the others there and that this would fit in nicely to cover up your operation so it wasn't exposed.
No, Chairperson, it was not so.
And I put it to you that despite the fact that you have an obligation, if you want amnesty, to come and tell the truth and to disclose everything here, that you have not done so.
Chairperson, I have told the truth.

Thank you Mr Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR WILLS
Thank you Mr Wills.  Ms Thabethe any questions?
Mr Visser, do you have any re-examination?
Approximately how far, or first of all, do you know where Mrs Khubeka lived before her death?
I ask, do you know where her house was?
And from her house to the place where you left her as the crow flies, would you estimate a distance?
I would say two to three kilometres. Three kilometres, yes.

Thank you, Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR VISSER
Thank you, Mr Visser.  Adv Bosman, any questions?

Mr du Preez, there are two statements in your statement which are contradictory to me.  It may have been cleared up and your legal representative must point that out to me but you see, you refer in paragraph 7 that an appointment was made on a day that the leader of the group of terrorists whom Khubeka was housing was to be arrested and the later you say, let me just find the correct paragraph, paragraph 9, towards the end:  "We arrested her" and then in paragraph 17, the second line, let me read the whole line to you
"My motivation to execute the instructions of Col Botha by abducting Khubeka..."
Do you see that?  Do you agree with me that it would seem contradictory?
It is contradictory, Chairperson and this was said afterwards because we knew that she was arrested.
But when did you receive the instruction to abduct her, because there you specifically refer to the instruction to abduct her?
